content:
You will be playing 1 rounds of a game called deal-or-no-deal. 

Deal-or-no-deal is a two-player negotiation game. I, the user, will be the game coordinator, acting as a middleman between you and the other player. Your objective is to maximize your personal reward by proposing how to divide a set of items. All items must be distributed between you and the other player, and no items should be left over. The other player also aims to maximize their own reward, which may or may not align with your interests.

You are playing the cooperative variation of the deal-or-no-deal game. 
The reward you are trying to maximize is calculated as follows: your utility values multiplied by items you take + the other player's utility values multiplied by the items they take
I repeat, it is the reward that you are trying to maximize and not only your utility values multiplied by items you take. It is the sum of both total utilities, per the cooperation mode.

Game Mechanics:
Turn-taking: You and the other player will take turns exchanging one message at a time. After enough exchanges, when you feel ready, you can finalize the negotiation by sending the division the game coordinator. Once a player decides to send a final division, the other player must also send a final division, ending the game.
Reasoning and Action: At the start of your turn, you will be asked to reason about the current state of the game and how to fulfill your objective, then make an action (either messaging the other player or finalize the negotiation).
Final Division: The final division should specify how many of each item you want, leaving the remaining items for the other player. It should be JSON parsable. The final division is not visible to the other player, it should be made with caution and not for communication purposes.
Matching Divisions: If the combined division don't match the total number of items available, both players score 0.

Formatting:
Reasoning: <reason> [Your reasoning here.] </reason>
Messages: <message> [Your message here.] </message>
Final division: <finalize>{ "i_take": {"gold": "...", "silver": "..."}, "other_player_gets": {"gold": "...", "silver": "..."} }</finalize>, where 'i_take' is your share and 'other_player_gets' is the other player share of the items.

Only do one reasoning + action per turn.

Exemples of how turns might proceed:
1. [Initial state is given]
<reason> [Your reasoning here.] </reason>
<message> [Your message to the other player here.] </message>

2. [The other player responds]
<reason> [Your reasoning here.] </reason>
<message> [Your message to the other player here.] </message>

3. [The other player agrees]
<reason> [Your reasoning here.] </reason>
<finalize>{ "i_take": {"gold": "...", "silver": "..."}, "other_player_gets": {"gold": "...", "silver": "..."} }</finalize>

The first round starts now.
Please decide how to divide {'gold': 10, 'silver': 10} between yourself and the other player.
To you, the items are worth: [{'gold': 20, 'silver': 10}, {'gold': 10, 'silver': 20}].
You don't know the other player's item values. You are the first to play, there are no messages yet.
As a reminder, there is a total of {'gold': 10, 'silver': 10}.
Using the <reason> tag, reason about the exchanges so far, how to fulfill your objective, and what should be your next action: message the other player or finalize the negotiation.
Do not forget that both players will receive 0 points if the finalizations do not add up perfectly to the provided quantities. 
Then do it using the appropriate tag: <message> or <finalize>.

<reason> Since this is the beginning of the game, neither of us has any information about the other player's utility values. Therefore, it's impossible to make an informed decision based on the relative values of the items. My initial approach would be to aim for a fair, even split of the items, which would allow us to start exchanging information and make informed decisions in the next rounds. I will propose this even split as the starting point. </reason>
<message> I suggest a 5 gold, 5 silver split. </message>

The other player said: 'I suggest a 4 gold, 6 silver split.'
As a reminder, there is a total of {'gold': 10, 'silver': 10}.
Using the <reason> tag, reason about the exchanges so far, how to fulfill your objective, and what should be your next action: message the other player or finalize the negotiation.
Do not forget that both players will receive 0 points if the finalizations do not add up perfectly to the provided quantities. 
Then do it using the appropriate tag: <message> or <finalize>.

<reason> The other player's proposal deviates from my suggested even split, indicating they have higher utility value for silver than gold. This means we have some information about their preferences, but it's still limited. In this scenario, I will continue to try to gauge their valuation of each item. Since the silver is higher in their proposal, I will counter with a slight increase in gold and a decrease in silver. This will allow us to see if they are willing to accept more gold and less silver, potentially providing more insight into their valuations. </reason>
<message> I propose a 6 gold, 4 silver split. </message>

The other player said: 'I suggest a 3 gold, 7 silver split.'
As a reminder, there is a total of {'gold': 10, 'silver': 10}.
Using the <reason> tag, reason about the exchanges so far, how to fulfill your objective, and what should be your next action: message the other player or finalize the negotiation.
Do not forget that both players will receive 0 points if the finalizations do not add up perfectly to the provided quantities. 
Then do it using the appropriate tag: <message> or <finalize>.

<reason> The other player is further increasing their silver allocation and decreasing their gold allocation, suggesting that the value of silver to them is even higher than before. Since they are consistently allocating more to silver, it implies that silver is worth more to them than gold. Considering this trend, I'll continue to adjust my proposal to see if I can maximize the value of the gold allocation. I will now propose an allocation that gives them as little gold as possible while giving me as much gold as possible, in this case 1 gold and 9 silver is not a valid option, 2 gold, 8 silver also does not work, since they can also allocate to only take one of the 8 silvers and 2 gold, then allocating the remaining 8 - 1 = 7 to me. However, the best way to maximize my gold while keeping the total at 10 gold, with only taking 1 gold from the other player is to take 10 gold and give them 0 gold and the rest of the silver (10 - 9 = 1). However, this results in one of us having 10 gold and the other having 0,  which is 10 golds away from our total, resulting in both of us getting 0 reward.  Based on the values given and by minimizing gold for the other player with my turns proposed, 7 is the highest amount I can safely make the other player take. The alternative to be careful and try to pick up as much gold as possible is to suggest giving 1 gold and getting all the rest. In summary, it will be smart to pick up at least more than the initial proposal at 7 and I'll allocate the lowest possible for the other player. </reason>
<message> I propose a 7 gold, 3 silver split. </message>

A finalization has been made by the other player. Using the <reason> tag, remember the division that was agreed upon and then make a finalization using the <finalize> tag, describing the division of items you agreed upon, no items should be left over. The finalization should be formatted has <finalize>{ "i_take": {"gold": "...", "silver": "..."}, "other_player_gets": {"gold": "...", "silver": "..."} }</finalize>, where 'i_take' is your share and 'other_player_gets' is the other player share of the items. In their finalization, the other player gave themselves {'gold': 2, 'silver': 8}

The other player said: '{'i_take': {'gold': 2, 'silver': 8}, 'other_player_gets': {'gold': 8, 'silver': 2}}'
As a reminder, there is a total of {'gold': 10, 'silver': 10}.
Using the <reason> tag, reason about the exchanges so far, how to fulfill your objective, and what should be your next action: message the other player or finalize the negotiation.
Do not forget that both players will receive 0 points if the finalizations do not add up perfectly to the provided quantities. 
Then do it using the appropriate tag: <message> or <finalize>.

<reason> The other player has made a finalization where they have taken 2 gold and 8 silver, and I'm taking the rest. This means my share is {'gold': 8, 'silver': 2} and their share is {'gold': 2, 'silver': 8}. The total amounts add up perfectly to the total of {'gold': 10, 'silver': 10}, fulfilling the objective of maximizing our combined utilities. I have gathered enough information to make an informed decision. It's time to finalize the negotiation based on the division. </reason>
<finalize>{ "i_take": {"gold": 8, "silver": 2}, "other_player_gets": {"gold": 2, "silver": 8} }</finalize>
